pyntacle.report.plotter module¶

class PlotGraph(graph: igraph.Graph)[source]¶

Bases: object

Rhis method creates a report according to the type of analysis run by pyntacle

logger = None¶

check if graph has node names and they are unique

plot_graph(path=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot graph to a specific file, in several formats. Available formats: “jpg”, “pdf”, “svg”, “png”

Parameters:path – optional - a path in which results will be plotted (deafulat is the current working directory)
set_edge_label(labels: list)[source]¶

Take a list corresponding to edge properties (e.g.: a graph attribute) [HUH?]

Param:labels: a list of lables (must be strings)
set_edge_widths(widths, attribute=None)[source]¶

Assign a series of colours stored in a dictionary to the igraph plot, based on the attribute values

Parameters:
  • widths (dict or list) – either a dictionary whose keys are graph attributes and the widths are either integers or floats e.g. {“foo”: 0.4} with “vasco” being in self.graph.vs()[“name”] or a list of the same length as number of node with widths inside
  • attribute – if colours is a dictionary, must be specified
set_layouts(layout='fruchterman_reingold', **kwargs)[source]¶

Define a series of layouts imported from the igraph package

Parameters:
  • layout – one of the following layouts: “circle”, “fruchterman_reingold”/”fr” (force directed), “kamada_kawai”/”kk” (force directed), “large_graph”/”lgl”, “random”, “reingold_tilford”, “rt” (for trees). Default is fruchterman_reingold
  • kwargs – a list of parameters that can be passed to each of the layout method
set_node_colours(colours, attribute=None)[source]¶

Assign a series of colours stored in a dictionary to the igraph plot, based on the attribute values

Parameters:
  • colours – either a dictionary whose keys are graph attributes and the colours are either RGB or literal colour names e.g. {“vasco”: “red”} with “vasco” being in self.graph.vs()[“name”] or a list of the same lenght as number of node with colours inside
  • attribute – if colours is a dictionary, must be specified
set_node_label(labels: list)[source]¶

Take a list corresponding to node properties (e.g.: a graph attribute)

Param:labels: a list of lables (must be strings)

  • shapes –

set_node_sizes(sizes, attribute=None)[source]¶

Assign a series of sizes stored as a list r a dictionary

Parameters:
  • widths (dict or list) – either a dictionary whose keys are graph attributes and the widths are either integers or floats e.g. {“foo”: 0.4} with “vasco” being in self.graph.vs()[“name”] or a list of the same lenght as number of node with widths inside
  • attribute – if colours is a dictionary, must be specified
